Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2 Consortium: Development of a Photon-Number-Resolving Detector System for Universal Quantum Computing
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

This award is for development of a photon-number-resolving detector for universal quantum computing. This is a collaboration between Prof. Olivier Pfster at the University of Virginia, Prof. Aaron Miller at Albion College, and Dr. Sae Woo Nam at the National Institute of Standards and Technology. The goal is the development of high performance transition-edge sensor (TES) superconducting photodetectors, recently demonstrated at NIST by Dr. Nam and by Prof. Miller, to be installed at the University of Virginia and used in quantum optics and quantum information experiments. Such detectors possess single-photon sensitivity, multiphoton resolution, and near-unity quantum efficiency, which makes them the ideal tool to explore the quantum nature of light by providing a complete measurement of its particle nature. The main emphasis will be placed on the creation and manipulation of quantum states of light possessing non-Gaussian Wigner quasiprobability distributions. Such states are essential to the implementation of universal quantum computing with continuous variables.

The broader impacts of the work are multifaceted. First and foremost is that this is an interdisciplinary effort between cutting-edge detector science and experimental quantum information. This interdisciplinary effort will involve students from Virginia participating in and learning TES technology, design, development, and fabrication, as well as NIST and Albion personnel participating in quantum optics and quantum information experiments at Virginia. Second, given the integration capabilities of the design, it is expected that a number of independent, fiber-coupled TES detectors will be available in the Virginia laboratory and usable remotely by experiments on adjacent tables or in neighboring rooms including novel teaching laboratories in quantum optics. These laboratories would explore the quantum nature of classical light via photon-number-resolved Hanbury Brown and Twiss experiments and generalized Hong-Ou-Mandel interferometry. Also, quantum computing research has stakes in fundamental physics, as well as Defense and National Security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award ''MRI-R2 Consortium: Development of a Photon-Number-Resolving Detector System for Universal Quantum Computing'' was dedicated to the design and construction of a cutting-edge scientific instrument for research in quantum information. This was done successfully as a collaboration between the University of Virginia --- UVa (Prof. Olivier Pfister), Albion College (Prof. Aaron Miller), and the National Institute of Standards and Technology --- NIST (Dr. Sae Woo Nam).

The question of the nature of light (wave or particle?) has been central to, and synonymous with, the progress of physics before the XXth century. Sir Isaac Newton favored a corpuscular theory of light, an assertion of considerable weight, obviously, which stood for almost a century before Young's work in 1801 started providing evidence for the wave nature of light, later confirmed by Maxwell's theory of electromagnetism. However, the birth of the XXth century saw the particle nature emerge again, thanks to Planck and Einstein, this time not in a manner exclusive of the wave nature, but complementary to it. Quantum physics was born. Since then, performing experiments on the particle nature of light has evolved from a sure way to address its quantum nature to a fundamental requirement for universal quantum computing using quantum fields. 

However, detection of light at the single photon level has been a challenge. First, one requires the detector's sensitivity to be at the single photon level. This was achieved a long time ago in photomultipliers and avalanche photodiodes, yet these detectors neither operate at unity quantum efficiency (probability of detecting each and every photon) nor do they offer the ability to resolve the photon number (a lot of experiments being therefore conducted at weak enough photon fluxes that no more than one photon is ever present at a given time). 

The transition-edge sensors (TES) developed by the group of Sae Woo Nam at NIST are a set of superconducting tungsten photodetector chips embedded in optical resonators. Specifically biased at the bottom of the steep superconducting transition, these detectors provide a signal proportional to the number of photons, at a very high quantum efficiency because of the photon storage provided by the optical resonator. The system operates at 100 mK and must therefore be enclosed in a cryostat, first cooled by a closed-circuit He-compressor fridge and further cooled by adiabatic demagnetization. The light is coupled from the experimental benches to the TES inside the cryostat by optical fiber throughputs.

The goals of this proposal were to design (at NIST and Albion), construct (at NIST and Albion), and install (at UVa) a TES system for the wavelength of 1064 nm, that of Nd:YAG lasers and of the optical parametric oscillators which are the quantum optical workhorses used in Pfister's group at UVa, where the TES system is to be used in subsequent experimental studies in quantum optics and quantum information. All the goals were met.

(i) A set of 8 fiber-coupled TES devices, and 4 uncoupled ones, was installed in a cryostat specially constructed by High Precision Devices, purchased with award funding. The TES detectors were preliminarily tested for efficiency, measurement noise, and photon-number resolving response. 5 out of 8 were initially found to be functional.

(ii) The whole apparatus was then shipped from NIST Boulder, CO, to UVa Charlottesville, VA, and installed in Pfister's lab. 

(iii) The TES was tested on two-photon emitting sources, whose nonclassical properties were confirmed by the observation of  quantum correlations between two TES modules, each receiving a photon of the emitted pair.
